Authors:
Elaine Cristina Francisco, João Nóbrega de almeida júnior,
Flávio Queiroz-Telles, Valério Rodrigues Aquino, Ana Verena A. Mendes,
Marcio Oliveira Silva, Paulo de Tarso O Castro, Thais Guimarães,
Vinicius Ponzio, Rosane C Hahn, Guilherme M Chaves, Arnaldo Lopes
Colombo
Title:
Emergence of Trichosporon asahii genotype 7 with limited
susceptibility to triazoles and amphotericin B in clinical samples
collected along 20 years
Keywords:
Trichosporon asahii, genotypes, epidemiology, antifungal
susceptibility, opportunistic infections
Abstract:
Trichosporon asahii is an opportunistic fungal pathogen
that can cause severe infections with high mortality rates. Azole
derivatives are considered the best-targeted therapy for T. asahii
invasive infections, but azole-resistant isolates have been reported in
different centres. In order to investigate the emergence of antifungal
resistance among clinical isolates of T. asahii, we analyzed the
genotypes distribution and the antifungal susceptibility profile among
284 isolates collected from different Brazilian centres between 1997 and
2019. Methods: Species identification was performed by sequence analysis
and phylogenetic relationships of the IGS1 region of the rDNA. Genotypes
were characterized based on haplotype networks. Antifungal
susceptibility testing for amphotericin B, fluconazole, voriconazole,
and posaconazole were processed using CLSI M27-4th ed. microdilution
broth method. Trends in the antifungal susceptibility profile of
Brazilian T. asahii isolates was investigated using epidemiological
cutoff values recently proposed. Results: In total, 284 T. asahii
isolates were tested. According to rDNA intergenic spacer sequencing
results, five different genotypes were found and isolates belonging to
the genotype 7 were detected in our series only after 2013. Genotype 7
isolates contributed to the higher minimal inhibitory concentration
values of voriconazole that have been documented in recent years.
Conclusions: Monitoring T. asahii genotypes distribution and antifungal
susceptibility profiles are warranted to prevent the spread of
azole-resistant isolates.
